TextEquiv.Unicode: Secondarily, let us believe that all
these sins of ours are pardoned & for
given of God, not for the acknowledg
ing and confessing of our sinnes, but
for the merit and bloud of the sonne of
God : not for our owne workes or me
rites, but for the truth and mercie or
grace of God. For we do plainely pro
sesse, saying: I believe the forgivenesse
of sins: Ve say not, I buy, or by gifts
doe get, or by workes obtaine the for
givenesse of sins, but I believe the for
givenesse of sinnes. And the worde re
mission or forgivenesse doth signifie a
free pardoning, by a metaphore taken
of creditors and debitors For the cre
ditor forgiveth the debitor, when hee
is not able to paye : therefore remissi
on is a forgiving according to the say
in of our saviour in the Gospell: A
certaine lender had two debitors: and
when they were not able to paie, he
forgave them both. Hereunto belong
eth that also in the Lords prayer: And
forgive us our debtes. For our debtes
are our sinnes, them doe we request to
be remitted, that is, to be forgiven us.
In this sense also, saith S. Paul: To
him that worketh is the reward recko
ned, not of grace, but of due debt: But
to him that worketh not, but belee
veth on him that justifieth the ungod
lie, his faith is counted for righteous
nesse: Even as David describeth the
blessednesse of that man unto whom
God imputeth righteousnesse without
workes, saying: Blessed are they whose
unrighteousnesse are forgiven, and
whose sinnes are covered. Blossed is
that man to whom the Lorde will not
impute sinne. Wherefore in respect of
us which have not wherewithall to
repaie, our sinnes are freely forgiven,
but in respect of Gods justice they are
forgiven for the merit and satistaction

Secondarily, let us believe that all these sins of ours are pardoned & for given of God, not for the acknowledg ing and confessing of our sinnes, but for the merit and bloud of the sonne of God : not for our owne workes or me rites, but for the truth and mercie or grace of God. For we do plainely pro sesse, saying: I believe the forgivenesse of sins: Ve say not, I buy, or by gifts doe get, or by workes obtaine the for givenesse of sins, but I believe the for givenesse of sinnes. And the worde re mission or forgivenesse doth signifie a free pardoning, by a metaphore taken of creditors and debitors For the cre ditor forgiveth the debitor, when hee is not able to paye : therefore remissi on is a forgiving according to the say in of our saviour in the Gospell: A certaine lender had two debitors: and when they were not able to paie, he forgave them both. Hereunto belong eth that also in the Lords prayer: And forgive us our debtes. For our debtes are our sinnes, them doe we request to be remitted, that is, to be forgiven us. In this sense also, saith S. Paul: To him that worketh is the reward recko ned, not of grace, but of due debt: But to him that worketh not, but belee veth on him that justifieth the ungod lie, his faith is counted for righteous nesse: Even as David describeth the blessednesse of that man unto whom God imputeth righteousnesse without workes, saying: Blessed are they whose unrighteousnesse are forgiven, and whose sinnes are covered. Blossed is that man to whom the Lorde will not impute sinne. Wherefore in respect of us which have not wherewithall to repaie, our sinnes are freely forgiven, but in respect of Gods justice they are forgiven for the merit and satistaction
Moreover, it is not the sinnes of a
few men, of one or two ages, or a fewe
and certaine number of sins are forgi
ven onely, but the sinnes of all men, of
all ages, the whole multitude of sins,
whatsoever is, and is called sin, whe
ther it be originall, or actuall, or any o
ther else, to be short all sinnes are for
given us. Which we do hereby learne,
because the onely sacrifice of Christ is
effectuall enough to wash away all the
offences of all sinners, which by faith
come to the mercie seat of Gods grace.
And yet by this we doe not teach men
to sinne, because the Lorde hath long
since made satisfaction for sinnes: but
if any man doe sinne, we teach him to
hope well, and not to despaire, but to
flee to the throne of Grace. For there
we say, that Christ sitting at the right
hande of the father, is the Lambe of
God that taketh away the fins of the
worlde. And in the Creede verily it is
expresly sayde: I believe the forgive
nesse of sinnes, and not of sinne. For
when we say of sinnes, we acknow
ledge that God forgiveth all finnes.
For to let passe the proofes hereof out
of the 2. 5 5. of Paul to the Bomanes,
those out of S. Iohn the Apostle & E
nangelist shall be susficent, who in his
Epistle testifieth and sayth: The bloud
of lesus Christ clenseth us from everie
sinne. Loe, he saith from everie sinne,
Hee, I say, that saith from everie one,
excepteth none, unlesse it be ye which ye
Lorde himelfe excepted, I meane the
sinne against the holy ghost, for which
the very same S. Iohn forbiddeth us
to pray. Againe also he saithr If we ac
knowledge our sinnes, God is faithfull
and just, to forgive us our sinnes, and
to clense us fro all our unrighteousnes,
The Apostle thought it not enough to
say barely, To forgive us our sinnes,

Moreover, it is not the sinnes of a few men, of one or two ages, or a fewe and certaine number of sins are forgi ven onely, but the sinnes of all men, of all ages, the whole multitude of sins, whatsoever is, and is called sin, whe ther it be originall, or actuall, or any o ther else, to be short all sinnes are for given us. Which we do hereby learne, because the onely sacrifice of Christ is effectuall enough to wash away all the offences of all sinners, which by faith come to the mercie seat of Gods grace. And yet by this we doe not teach men to sinne, because the Lorde hath long since made satisfaction for sinnes: but if any man doe sinne, we teach him to hope well, and not to despaire, but to flee to the throne of Grace. For there we say, that Christ sitting at the right hande of the father, is the Lambe of God that taketh away the fins of the worlde. And in the Creede verily it is expresly sayde: I believe the forgive nesse of sinnes, and not of sinne. For when we say of sinnes, we acknow ledge that God forgiveth all finnes. For to let passe the proofes hereof out of the 2. 5 5. of Paul to the Bomanes, those out of S. Iohn the Apostle & E nangelist shall be susficent, who in his Epistle testifieth and sayth: The bloud of lesus Christ clenseth us from everie sinne. Loe, he saith from everie sinne, Hee, I say, that saith from everie one, excepteth none, unlesse it be ye which ye Lorde himelfe excepted, I meane the sinne against the holy ghost, for which the very same S. Iohn forbiddeth us to pray. Againe also he saithr If we ac knowledge our sinnes, God is faithfull and just, to forgive us our sinnes, and to clense us fro all our unrighteousnes, The Apostle thought it not enough to say barely, To forgive us our sinnes,
